title: Survivor in the mist
body:
## CHAPTER THIRTEEN

### Rain of Fire

![(Illustration 15)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/8na45iPrcwLVYzuSuAPi6.jpg?height=1500&width=3000)

Sadly, right after Monk and Davis have officially become spec ops, they both never assigned on a mission together like they always hoped for. While on the other hand, Monk has always wanted to become a gunship gunner instead of a combatant, and he worked very hard to achieved his position. He loved all generations of gunship ever since he was a kid and it was what motivated him to join the military in the first place.

Davis on the other hand has only one wish, a combatant. He enjoys the battlefield rather than bragging around the neighborhood with his clean military uniform. Besides Davis's wife, even Monk sometimes fears losing his best friend because of Davis's decision. But after Davis survived on many battlefields where once he was badly shot, beat up, stabbed, and yet still alive and never back out from going into a battlefield, Monk finally chooses to stop worrying and tries to be more supportive.

Despite Davis got beat up pretty badly by the enemy, Catherine, Davis'wife has also beaten the hell out of Davis even more at the beginning of their marriage before Mike was born. Simply to say, Catherine and Davis's love affair is kinda complicated.

In mid-2024, Monk was assigned to give air support for Davis and his team on a classified spec ops mission to take out a terrorist training base somewhere inside the Middle East. The mission's name was “Rain of fire” and it was one of the most difficult missions they ever encountered. The terrain was complex and difficult, even Davis almost blew it. Along with his team, they were pinned down from every angle by the terrorist group since it was a close-distance battlefield in the mountainous region.

Monk always thought he can always be helpful if they went on the same mission together, but on that day, he left helpless inside a gunship full of ammo and armaments while hearing his best friend got attacked from every direction on the radio. That of course, is not until Davis has finally gone haywire and requested Monk a direct rapid fire from the gunship to the designated enemy target based solely on Davis's visual and verbal guidance. On one hand, it was a 50:50 chance because if Monk missed the target just once, then Davis and his team were gone forever. While on the other hand, if Davis didn’t make that risky decision, then he and the rest of his team will never have had the chance to survive.

That day, the mission name "Rain of fire" has turned into an actual and real-time event as Monk keeps firing the gunship mighty arsenal to the battlefield solely on Davis visual instructions. In less than eighty seconds of hell, the terrorist strongholds were finally turned to dust and the battle advantage turned to Davis and his team's favor.

***August 2025. A crucial moment inside the First-Ring of the misty forest***

![(Illustration 16)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/wR_EafVkpXebSNXWjAxlX.jpg?height=1500&width=3000)

Davis has just finished calculating the safest way to save the little girl’s life, at least on his mind. He has decided not to run continuously for around sixty seconds without having the ability to control what happen during those sixty seconds. He needs to make sure the incoming horde of the undead does not get too close to the little girl while he moves forward trying to save her life. So, he decides to do something far worse than it already has!

## CHAPTER FOURTEEN

### Sometimes a man gotta do what a man gotta do…

![(Illustration 17)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/ldm-2hc0pF9hY3UXkI4AE.jpg?height=1500&width=3000)

***17:09. The hostile ground inside the First-Ring of the misty forest.***

To sprint run for sixty seconds in rough and uneven terrain of the misty forest will make Davis blind to what lies in front of him and the surrounding. He may fall from running too fast, or hurt his leg, or any other worse possible scenarios. Davis knows he encounters a seemingly impossible situation because what he needs is to have a moment of control over the hostile ground while he marches forward until he reaches the little girl’s position. Plain and simple.

He immediately calls Eagle-One through the radio and asks for a backup to do whatever he sees fit as a better chance to save the little girl's life and his own.

Davis: “Batman-five to Eagle-One, requesting direct air support. Break. Monk! We need to do another round of ‘Rain of fire’. Break. I ran out of options and need your confirmation. Do you copy? Over.”

After several seconds of delay, a response from Eagle-One comes in.

Monk: “Eagle-One to Batman-five, rescue the survivor and do what’s needed to be done. I got your back. Break. Direct air support is affirmative. Break. Requesting weapon guidance and the survivor’s coordinate. Break. Opening a secure two-way radio channel until the threat is eliminated. Do you copy? Over.”

By opening a secure two-way radio channel, Davis and Monk can now communicate directly without any interruption from other radio frequencies.

Davis has no time to explain the ongoing situation since the longer they talk, it’ll be too late to save the little girl’s life.

He has calculated the horde will reach the little girl’s position faster than he does even if he runs continuously because the distance between the horde and the little girl is only forty meters away. So, whatever Davis plans to do, he needs to do it now!

Before answering Monk's radio call, Davis looks to his surroundings one last time. As he sure the coast is clear, he promptly stands up and takes off his ghillie suit, straps his sniper to his back. He takes out the 357 Magnum Desert Eagle from the belt holster and unlocks it, then he unlocks his MP5A3 submachine gun which he straps onto his right shoulder.

Davis: "Batman-Five to Eagle-One, Roger-Tango Eagle-One. Break. The survivor’s coordinate is approximately one hundred and forty-five meters North of the current beacon’s position. I explain as we go along, just don’t drop anything under one hundred and sixty meters from the current beacon’s position. I repeat, don’t shot under one hundred and sixty meters from the current beacon’s position heading North. Do you copy? Over.”

Monk: “Eagle-One to Batman-five, your current beacon’s position is detected. Break. The survivor’s approximate coordinate is marked. Mapping a secure zone from the current beacon’s position heading North to one hundred and sixty meters ahead. Break. We have you on visual. You may proceed immediately. Do you copy? Over.”

Davis: “Batman-five to Eagle-One, Copy that. We are hot in ... three ... two ... one ... HAIL MARY!”

Davis responds to Monk's radio call by holding the Desert Eagle with his right hand and starts marching forward towards the little girl’s position. He yelled "HAIL MARY!" on the radio to Eagle-One to let Monk know that the deadly battle between a one-man ground spotter and a gunship gunner against a horde of the undead to save a little girl's life has finally begun.

## CHAPTER FIFTEEN

### The conductor of a deadly orchestra

![(Illustration 18)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/eSDrhl_0YTtOVu7vuoxhF.jpg?height=1500&width=3000)

Davis has started to brisk walk towards a horde of beasts to save a little girl’s life who is stranded somewhere in between. He has also calculated the approximate time and steps needed to reach the destination. It is true that no matter how fast he walks, it takes longer than running; at least ninety seconds or more and nearly two hundred steps before reaching the little girl. The difference in time is significant, but his final decision is better because he can focus on the survivor’s position and safety, as well as the incoming horde of the undead, and also for his own safety instead of putting himself in a vulnerable position. Now he is in control, and with the help from the gunship arsenal securing the perimeter from above the sky, hopefully, he’ll also have the power over the hostile horde of the undead.

As a ground spotter who will act on Monk's behalf, Davis will give instructions on what type of weapons will be used, and where to drop them?

Despite Eagle-One has a visual of Davis's location through his beacon, Monk cannot have a precise vision of where the little girl and the horde of the undead are located since the mist inside the First-Ring of the misty forest is denser after sunset. Once the Ghostrider makes its lowest possible altitude and makes a pylon turn maneuver above the designated target zone, Monk will use thermal imaging cameras to view the ground. He can see in total darkness, through light fog, rain, and snow, but the distance Monk sees will still be affected by the atmospheric conditions from inside the First-Ring of the misty forest; and that is where Davis needs to do his part as a ground spotter, or perhaps, a deadly battlefield conductor.

In his walking position, Davis has a better visual of the incoming horde, and he is trying to eliminate the nearest horde that keeps approaching the little girl’s position.

Davis: "Batman-Five to Eagle-One, Requesting Griffin. Break. The target distance is one hundred and seventy-five meters bearing South of the beacon. Break. Fire at will. Over."

Monk: "10-4 Batman-Five. We have a visual of the incoming horde. Break. Delivering the Griffin now. Over."

Seconds later, the AGM-176 Griffin laser-guided missile which is known for its low collateral damage hit the ground at the incoming horde.

"KABOOM!"

The explosive sound of Griffin's missile slightly shakes ground zero and has broken the silence that once blankets the misty forest for quite a long time.

In their first attempt, Monk and Davis have succeeded to eliminate the first line of the incoming horde. Davis makes a status report to Eagle-One,

“Direct hit Eagle-One. Break. Well done, the survivor is safe. Break. Stand by. Over."

Monk: "Eagle-one standing by. Over."

## CHAPTER SIXTEEN

### They are coming!

![(Illustration 19)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/TSMkQwYl1b-klT35uh_2c.jpg?height=1500&width=3000)

The evening starts to enter the night, as inside the First-Ring of the misty forest becomes darker and turns eerie every minute. The evening storm hovers above the battleground made the shining bright moon hides behind the cloudy storm on one gloomy and scary night. The early August wind that used to be celebrated by many before Z-day as a sign to greet the coming Autumn now sends fear down to the bones for those who even stay securely indoors.

For most field soldiers from other units at Gila Headquarters, going for a tour of duty into The First-Ring of the misty forest for whatever reason is like going to hell, a cursed destination. HQ has also forbidden any soldiers or survivors from the military base to enter inside the First-Ring of the misty forest, well, except for Davis. He insisted Monk for letting him sets up a recon post, a small treehouse sitting high above the ground on one of the highest and strongest trees that can fit only for one person, Davis.

***August 2025, Outpost-One.***

For the last one hundred and fifty meters, the Bravo-One team has been walking closely and cautiously at a slow pace from the open field where they were dropped by the helo a few minutes ago. Now they have arrived at Outpost-One where Officer Davis used to recon the area for the past weeks. When the Griffin missile struck the earth and exploded on impact with a loud noise it echoes throughout the misty forest and was vaguely heard by the Bravo-One team.

Joe and Danny were the first to hear the echo and simultaneously they both raised their hands signaling the rest of the team to stop. They froze for a while until Kevin, the Bravo-One leader gives another military hand signal telling them to stop and set up a secure defense perimeter around the vicinity. They quickly form a diamond formation that resembles a twelve-hour clock position. Kevin as the team leader position himself at twelve o’clock, Stanley at three o’clock, Joe takes the position at six, and Danny at nine o’clock. They all kneel on the ground and hold their weapons steadily at gunpoint. Each man is facing different wind directions to make sure the defense perimeter is secure from any incoming hostile activity.

As they remain watchful in silence, Stanley feels tense and mutter over the situation,

"... It's going to be one hell of a night, and that is one music I don't want to hear inside this creepy place..."

After a lot of experiences post-Z-day, everyone knows too well that loud noises attract more undead rather than getting rid of them. It’s not because Davis doesn't know about it but as he said before, he has run out of options although he is also aware that what he is trying to do is like sending a feast invitation for the undead.

## CHAPTER SEVENTEEN

### The flash of terror

![(Illustration 20)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/iBd6Fbc8qjBh1BNkDxP5b.jpg?height=1500&width=3000)

On that late unfriendly evening, as the Griffin missile exploded inside the misty forest, it didn’t only make a loud noise but also flashes in the dark. The instant bright flash helps Davis to have a better visual of the hostile horde position and the little girl.

Davis sees a small group of shamblers closing in from thirty degrees Eastside. The approximate distance is twenty-five meters away from where the first group was hit by the Griffin.

To make sure he has the correct angle, Davis raises his right arm straight forward while holding the Desert Eagle, and then he shifts his arm slightly to the right side making a thirty degrees angle aiming his handgun to the last approximate location of the incoming shamblers.

Davis: "Batman-Five to Eagle-One, Requesting Griffin. Break. Target distance is one hundred and forty-five meters, thirty degrees North East heading South West of the beacon. Fire when ready. Over."

Monk: “Eagle-One to Batman-Five. We have a visual of the incoming hostile target. Break. Delivering the Griffin now. Over.”

In just a short moment, the Griffin made a precise hit and landed on one of the shamblers directly instead of hitting the ground. The explosion delivers another instant bright flash to the dark misty forest.

"KABOOM!"

When the Griffin missile exploded, Davis can see several shamblers closing in again not far from behind the last group that was torn to pieces by the Griffin missile. As Davis gets closer to the little girl’s position, it also makes the distance between him and the horde of the undead closer. He wants to make sure the rest of the horde will not be too close once he reaches the little girl’s position, and while he brisks walking steadily, he calls Eagle-One for another assistance.

Davis: "Batman-Five to Eagle-One. Direct hit! Good job. Break. Requesting ten second-round of 30mm Autocannon. Break. Target is thirty-three degrees North-East, distance one hundred and forty meters heading South West of the beacon. Do you copy? Over."

Monk: “Eagle-One to Batman-Five, Roger-Tango Batman-Five. We have a visual of the hostile horde. Firing now, Over."

Throughout the time, the Eagle-One pilot keeps making a pylon turn above the designated target on its safest possible altitude above the misty forest, and when Monk fires the gunship 30mm GAU-23 automatic side-firing chain gun, Davis can hear directly the continues ten seconds round burst of its terrifying sound. Like a rain of bright fiery steel falling from the sky, it hits the targeted zone.

"RATATATATATATATATATTATATATATA!"

Although Davis can't visually confirm if the bullets made a direct hit or not? But knowing through his years of experience on the battlefield that whatever is moving before it gets rained down by that 30mm speeding bullet, now it will not going to move anywhere, permanently!

Officer Davis is currently sixty-five meters from the little girl’s position where she is still helpless lying half-unconscious on the ground.

At this point, Davis hopes the little girl could turn conscious and start moving again because he wants to ask the gunship to drop something that could eliminate more of the incoming hostile horde nearby because the farther distance they both get from the hostile horde, then the better chance for both of them to escape.

## CHAPTER EIGHTEEN

### Ocean of nightmare

![(Illustration 21)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/_LY74pz_bK6nICKRyPqEz.jpg?height=1500&width=3000)

So far Officer Davis's plan is working well. He only needs to brisk walk for another fifty meters to save the survivor. The closest horde of the undead is now fifty-five meters away from the little girl’s position and keeps closing in but they walk slower than Davis.

As he gets closer, the horrifying sound that comes from the horde of the undead turns louder and felt nearer. Officer Davis feels terrified and he could not imagine how horrifying those hours of experience must be for the little girl to be chased alone by a horde of undead inside the dark and misty forest? Yet she somehow survives, but how? It seems too miraculous rather than coincidental. Who is she? Where did she come from? Is she part of a survivor's group? If that is the case, then could there be more survivors inside the First-Ring of the mist? Could Catherine and Mike still be alive after all this time? Hope and despair are battling inside Davis's heart and mind but somehow he just doesn't know which side to believe. While keep walking ahead, he knows there are more questions inside his mind about the little girl in a red dress than anything else right now. The passion for answers makes him vigilant and he is ready to do whatever it takes to make sure the little girl falls into his arm rather than to the beasts.

Davis has reached less than forty meters away from the little girl and he does not want to wait any longer. He calls Monk through the radio after he sees the horde has reached a distance of forty-five meters from the little girl’s position.

Davis: “Batman-Five to Eagle-One, Requesting GBU and impact countdown. Break. The target distance is approximately one hundred and ten meters coming from the North and heading South to the beacon. Break. Fire when ready. Over.”

Davis has requested one of the most powerful arsenals in AC-130J Ghostrider disposal. GBU-39 SDB (Small Diameter Bomb) is one of the deadliest smart bombs in the history of modern warfare. It is a smaller version from its big brother, the GBU-43/B which is known as the Mother of All Bomb (MOAB).

Davis knew GBU-39 SDB's destructive capability and the post-explosion shock waves that happen after it made an impact on the target.

Before the explosion took place, Davis has to be prepared to avoid injury because he is only thirty meters away from the little girl and around eighty meters from the horde of the undead. He requested an impact countdown while the GBU glides its way to the designated target. Once exploded, the GBU will flash with high intensity of brightness to the surrounding zone; and Davis does not want to miss that out.

Monk: "Eagle-One to Batman-Five. Target is visual and locked. Break. Delivering the GBU, now. Countdown impact on ... three... two…brace for impact!"

As the countdown reaches 'two', Davis quickly jumps forward facing the ground while he closes both ears and tries to keep his eyes open as he possibly could to see the overall situation before he reaches the little girl's position.

The GBU exploded with a tremendous explosion, it also sends instant flash and shock waves to the surrounding area.

"KABOOM!!"

Davis can feel the ground trembles heavily. For a split second, the GBU blast dominates over the noisy sound coming out from the horde of the undead. Several trees fell to the ground and send the rest to scatter all over the targeted blast zone. At that point, Davis does not want to know what other parts are included in the flying debris.

Davis is still lying on the ground, he can see the mist, debris, and smoke mingled together. Although he has memorized the little girl's last known position before the explosion took place, now he can not see where it is; and the fact is, he cannot see anything farther than two meters away.

Davis hopes he did not make a mistake for requesting Monk to drop a high explosive bomb, but he is desperate, and he has no other option to save the little girl unless the horde of the undead is pushed back farther away.

Several things enter Davis's mind simultaneously but first, he needs to stay focus to reach the little girl's position and rescue her as soon as possible because when the GBU bomb exploded and illuminate the surrounding area, Davis was pretty sure he did not see a horde, but an army of horde behind the first one. Without delay, he crawls forward for several meters ahead then he quickly stands up and starts brisks walking again to the little girl's last known position as he has memorized it.

Davis’s position from the little girl is fifteen meters away but the dense mist mixed with hazes of dust and smoke caused by the blast still blankets the area. It makes him blind to anything farther than three meters away. Once the terrifying scream from the horde of the undead has echoed again in the air, Davis starts moving around and felt helpless. He raises both arms and holds the Desert Eagle at gunpoint, he aims at anything that moves behind the dense mist or making sounds nearby until all of the sudden...

**(To be continued)**

title: Web3's Not So Secret Weapon
body:
The open secret to Web3’s growth is its power to manifest self fulfilling prophecies. How? By enlisting **Mission Driven Users (MDUs)**. Let me elaborate with a thought experiment.

### The A Side

Imagine you, my esteemed reader, have a start-up idea. You want to disrupt Fiverr.  You want to do that by setting up another talent marketplace that charges less than half their take-rate on transactions (10% vs Fiverr’s \~25%). How? Your plan is to only use incentivized referral programs to attract both the talent and the clients to your marketplace. Your bet is that you can then minimize spend on other sales and marketing and *voila*: your blended CAC is slashed.

Well, you’d be unlikely to progress much further than a ppt deck. Incentivized referral programs are now [standard practice](https://www.reforge.com/brief/5-ways-to-create-viral-products#iBIwEkeVfOFmteqzNhcxCw) where they make sense. You won’t crack a sustainable advantage with them, even IF you manage to solve the cold start problem.

You would have a tough time convincing investors. Or even entice your discerning users with a lower take rate promise.

The A side is a no-go from the start.

### The B Side

In walks [web3](https://twitter.com/cdixon/status/1444072365822857219?s=20).

[https://twitter.com/cdixon/status/1442201625590779909](https://twitter.com/cdixon/status/1442201625590779909)

You can now use code to reward ‘equity’ in exchange for valuable user actions. At scale!

So you take your deck and update it. Instead of selling equity to investors and using the proceeds to fund your referral program; you bypass the middleman and offer the equity directly to your user base. For every successful referral, they now receive a small fraction of the equity in the marketplace. Seems like a subtle change at first. You wonder if it would even fundamentally change your unit economics assumptions.

Yet, the B-side uplift could be profound.

### What’s the uplift hypothesis?

To start with, you now have a powerful narrative to rally users: *a low-cost marketplace owned and governed by those who help create it*.

Much more moving than *“I will offer you 10% instead of 25%”.*

When your users buy into your vision, they pay more attention to what they can do to help you. Not solely out of the generosity of their spirits. They know that helping you earns them your equity. And **access** to your early stage equity is worth more to them than cash. They can unlock asymmetric returns that until now have been inaccessible to all but a selected few founders and VCs.

**The narrative, the agency and the motive are the three powerful ingredients that give you your secret weapon: Mission Driven Users (MDUs).** MDUs have a lot of similarities to early employees of a mission driven company. They go above and beyond base expectations:

* MDUs dig much deeper into their contact books and spend much more social capital to promote your marketplace compared to normal users. [Braintrust](https://www.usebraintrust.com/) - the first user-owned talent marketplace (and one of the most intriguing non finance web3 projects) - has created a global community of [700k freelancers](https://www.usebraintrust.com/blog/growth-report-24) (pending confirmation) and $35m in gross service volume run rate one year after launch with “[zero marketing dollars spent outside their referral engine](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J6upkcecUpE)”. And they already have enterprises like Goldman Sachs, Nestle, and Nike working with them (though credit for these also goes to the experienced [founding team](https://www.usebraintrust.com/about))
* MDUs are stickier and more forgiving. Look at the passion with which the Ethereum developer ecosystem perseveres despite persistent challenges around [scalability, cost and volatil](https://www.notboring.co/p/own-the-internet)ity. Keeping with the Braintrust example, the “website feedback” channel on its [Discord Serve](https://discord.gg/rgUS9aHFCB)r is filled with constructive feedback from its 45k members. Think about the probability of you giving detailed and continuous feedback to a young start-up you’ve tested as a user, when there are plenty of existing alternatives!
* MDUs may even contribute to the operations. In Braintrust, community members participate in day to day operations by [vetting talent, creating L&D content, or even contributing code to the development of the platform](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J6upkcecUpE). Bounty programs, where token prizes are offered for completion of a specific project by the community, are standard practice in web3. Key advantages of bounty programs compared to typical crowdfunding projects are (a) deep familiarity of participants with the project and its context; and (b) alignment of the participants interest with the outcome of the project beyond a one-off transaction

In short, MDUs can reduce your CAC, increase your LTV and improve your operating leverage. You just might be able to slash your take rate after all. Your marketplace is starting to look disruptive.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/whuy8lbBb4OAyeuKKXnOO.png?height=1423&width=2880)

### Of course there is always a ‘but’

Before rushing out to start your user owned marketplace - there are a few points to worth considering:

1. *Equity incentives might not resonate in all corners of the market.* A more risk-averse user persona (e.g. freelance lawyer or management consultants) or more cash strapped ones (eg [ride hailing drivers](https://techcrunch.com/2018/03/02/mit-study-shows-how-much-driving-for-uber-or-lyft-sucks/) pre pandemic) may put more value on cash today than the equity you offer them. If cash is worth more to your users, it would be harder to align incentives for the long term and beyond an initial transaction. And financial user incentives in general may not be appropriate at all in some corners: enterprise users or public sector employees
2. *The MDU effect may wear off at scale.* When your tokens are accessible by everyone and you’ve scaled to a certain point; your MDU effect is likely to wear off. Your users won’t have privileged access to the upside. And the upside is more limited now. And they will have less incremental impact in helping you grow further. At some point owning a Braintrust token will not be dissimilar to owning a Fiverr stock with more influence. So you would have to make sure you have other growth engines in place by then to sustain your advantage
3. *Tokens are not free.* Tokens can be many things: utility tokens (similar to loyalty points, usable within the ecosystem) or governance tokens (similar to equities and tradable for cash usually). But they are not free. The former has an opportunity cost of lost revenue in one way or another. The latter is the equity you have sold to your user instead of an investor. The challenge you will face in both scenarios is that it is very difficult for an early stage project to put a dollar amount on these and make informed decisions on your spend
4. *Your valuation becomes a compounding loop.* As your valuation grows, your MDUs are more incentivized to help you grow, and their actions help grow your marketplace which in turn leads to your valuation increasing. A virtuous cycle that’s missing in traditional companies. But the reverse will also be true. Crypto market trends push your valuations down. Your MDUs may become less inclined to earn your tokens. Your growth engine slows. Your marketplace is now worth less. Your MDUs are even less excited to help you grow the marketplace
5. *Token issuance could become more strictly regulated in the US.* There is some uncertainty about what type of token would the [SEC consider an equity](https://www-cdn.law.stanford.edu/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Mendelson_20180129.pdf). The stricter the SEC’s interpretation of the Howey Test vis-a-vis tokens is, the more cost prohibitive it would be for you to use tokens as an answer to your cold start problem

### Should you be taking this experiment?

All the said, will your marketplace be as disruptive as your pitchdeck claims? The answer is a very confident: maybe! Nuance is definitely less exciting, but hopefully more compelling.

But here’s a checklist that might help you assess if your marketplace lands on the ‘yes’ side of the spectrum:

* Is equity (ie promise of asymmetric returns at a future date) a meaningful incentive for your users?
* Do you have a compelling narrative to capture their imagination?
* Do you have a clear set of actions they can perform to help (and earn your tokens)?
* Do you have some initial ideas on how to sustain an edge once you scale and your MDUs naturally transition into being just ‘U’s

Tick these boxes and dive in. Web3’s potential is mind bending and it’s by no means limited to user owned marketplaces.

Or if you want to learn more, here is a non-exhaustive list of resources I found very helpful:

* Educational material: [Andreessen Horrowitz Crypto Start-up School](https://a16z.com/crypto-startup-school/)
* Books: [Token Economy](https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/54222022-token-economy), [Blockchain Basics](https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/34137265-blockchain-basics), or [The Infinite Machine](https://www.goodreads.com/en/book/show/50175330-the-infinite-machine)
* Join [SeedClub’s Discord](https://discord.gg/42UjJskuEF)
* Packy McCormick’s Essays on [Ethereum](https://www.notboring.co/p/own-the-internet), [Solana](https://www.notboring.co/p/solana-summer), and [DAOs](https://www.notboring.co/p/the-cooperation-economy-)
* Listen to [The Defiant](https://thedefiant.io/podcast/) or [The Bankless](http://podcast.banklesshq.com/) podcasts

### About Me

I’ve spent the past seven years building and scaling marketplaces in product or leadership roles. Before that I was a strategy consultant. At the time of writing this article, I’m a web3 newbie; \~2 months into the journey. If you see any flaws in my logic, please reach out to me and help me learn more. You can find me on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/AmiraliMohajer). Or on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/amiralimohajer/).

### Credits

* Cover photo by [Alina Grubnyak](https://unsplash.com/@alinnnaaaa)
* Growth frameworks alluded to are by [Reforge](https://www.reforge.com/). I highly recommend their courses/content

title: Automatically Manage your Fantasy Premier League Team with Python and AWS Lambda.
body:
![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0\*RO_EW0_J3ZnAHM-2)

Over the past month, my old post on [automatically managing your Fantasy Premier League](https://levelup.gitconnected.com/automatically-manage-your-fantasy-premier-league-team-with-python-fpl-pandas-docker-and-aws-ea373097a3c7) (FPL) team has gained a lot of traction. However, I’m not happy with it as a tutorial for a few reasons.

\#1 Issues with how the library returned the data lead to some unnecessary lines of code which could be improved.

\#2 I used [iterrows()](https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.iterrows.html) which is pretty much always terrible and should be avoided.

\#3 The Fantasy Premier League’s “Fixture Difficulty Rating” is terrible and never accurate, I want to use a better metric.

\#4 It relied on using Docker and AWS ECS Fargate, this isn’t necessarily bad as they are important technologies to learn for beginner to intermediate programmers (which this blog is aimed at), however, setting up Docker on a Windows machine (the most popular OS despite my love of Linux) is a pain that shouldn’t be part of a simple and fun project like a Fantasy Football bot.

I will still leave it up as it is a useful guide to the FPL library but I’ve decided to revisit the project with the intention of making it simpler by:

· Only using Requests and Pandas libraries.

· Using AWS Lambda with a layer for Pandas.

I think this will be a big improvement as if you can do a repetitive task like switching players with Lambda, you probably should as it is the cheapest service on AWS.

I would also like to add that if you use this tutorial to manage multiple teams your account is at risk of getting banned, like [the leading player of FPL did recently](https://twitter.com/LiveFPLnet/status/1426781613694889988?s=08).

For this tutorial you will need an AWS account, an FPL account and a Python environment.

## Goal:

We want to have our Fantasy Premier League team update each week without us doing anything.

## Road map:

We are going to need to achieve a few things to get this to work.

1\. We are going to need to get data on which players are in our team, data on Premier League teams, data on Premier League players and data on what fixtures are coming up.

2\. We need to know what number gameweek is coming up and we want to know if a deadline is within 24 hours so we only make a change before the deadline.

3\. We need to give a weighting to each player on our selected team based on their form, their upcoming fixtures and whatever other data we decide to use and pick one to transfer out.

4\. We need to give a weighting to each player that we could potentially pick based on their form, their upcoming fixtures and whatever other data we decide to use and pick one to transfer in.

5\. We need to give a weighting to each player on our selected team based on their form, their upcoming fixtures and whatever other data we decide to use and pick 11 players to start and which one is captain.

6\. We need to post our team to the website using the FPL API.

7\. We need to make a Lambda layer that includes Pandas.

8\. We need to deploy our code to Lambda and add a trigger to run the code every day.

## 0. Set Up

We need to get our user id from FPL (Fantasy Premier League). If you go to the “points” section of the website you will see the url looks like this “https://fantasy.premierleague.com/entry/user_id[/event/2](https://fantasy.premierleague.com/entry/1892301/event/2)”. The 6993864 is my teams user ID, yours will be different. We will pass in our email, password and user_id into the update team method. You can use environment variables if you want to keep the values private.

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*tMLSKUKj3V1EElOn6SY-iw.png)

To set up your python environment, run the following commands for Windows:

```
python -m venv venv
source venv/Scripts/activate
pip install pandas
pip install requests
pip install datetime
```

Our main that will be triggered is called lambda_handler as that is the default name on AWS Lambda, event and context are mandatory fields.

```
def lambda_handler(event, context):
    email = "your_email"
    password = "your_password"
    user_id = "your_user_id"
    update_team(email, password,user_id)
```

## 1 & 2. Getting the Data & Checking to Run

Following this post, I made a method to help with the get requests.

```
def get(url):
    response = requests.get(url)
    return json.loads(response.content)
```

The API endpoint that provides the vast majority of data is “https://fantasy.premierleague.com/api/bootstrap-static/”. Once we get the response we make dataframes out of elements, teams and events. Players are typically referred to as “elements” in the API and gameweeks are events.

```
def get_data():    players =  get('https://fantasy.premierleague.com/api/bootstrap-static/')
    players_df = pd.DataFrame(players['elements'])
    teams_df = pd.DataFrame(players['teams'])
    events_df = pd.DataFrame(players['events'])
```

We need to next calculate out what gameweek we are in before getting the fixtures. We will use the events_df for this as it has every gameweeks start date in it.

```
    today = datetime.now().timestamp()
    events_df = events_df.loc[events_df.deadline_time_epoch>today]
    gameweek =  fixtures_df.iloc[0].id
```

At this point, since we have todays timestamp we can add 24 hours using [timedelta](https://docs.python.org/3/library/datetime.html#timedelta-objects) and see if a deadline occurs. This lets us decide whether to run the full program or exit immediately, saving running time on AWS Lambda.

```
if check_update(fixtures_df) == False:
     print("Deadline Too Far Away")
     exit(0)def check_update(df):

        today = datetime.now()
    tomorrow=(today + timedelta(days=1)).timestamp()
    today = datetime.now().timestamp()
    df = df.loc[df.deadline_time_epoch>today]

        deadline = df.iloc[0].deadline_time_epoch
    if deadline<tomorrow:
        return True
    else:
        return False
```

Now that we have our gameweek we can send a request to the API for the upcoming fixtures.

```
fixtures = get('https://fantasy.premierleague.com/api/fixtures/?event='+str(gameweek))
fixtures_df = pd.DataFrame(fixtures)
```

Before returning all the data, I want to do some cleaning first. You can inspect the “players_df” and you will notice that all the fields for “chance_of_playing_this_round” are NaN. This field will remain NaN until the player gets injured, we want to [fill](https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.fillna.html) all NaNs with 100.

```
players_df.chance_of_playing_next_round = players_df.chance_of_playing_next_round.fillna(100.0)players_df.chance_of_playing_this_round = players_df.chance_of_playing_this_round.fillna(100.0)
```

You will also notice that the players team name will not appear, only the teams ID.

We want the team name in the fixtures dataframe and the player dataframe to make any investigations clearer. There are a few ways to achieve this, such as doing a merge but we will do a [mapping](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.Series.map.html) instead as it is a lot lighter and faster.

We make a dictionary from the id to the team name in the team dataframe.

```
teams=dict(zip(teams_df.id, teams_df.name))
```

Then we can map this into new columns in the players dataframe and the fixtures dataframe.

```
players_df['team_name'] = players_df['team'].map(teams)
fixtures_df['team_a_name'] = fixtures_df['team_a'].map(teams)
fixtures_df['team_h_name'] = fixtures_df['team_h'].map(teams)
```

In the teams dataframe you will notice that each team has a rating for how strong they are away and at home. In my last post I used the FDR field in the fixtures dataframe but it makes more sense to use this rating as it is more accurate. We can create a dictionary of the teams away and home strength and map it to home and away team in the fixtures dataframe.

```
home_strength=dict(zip(teams_df.id, teams_df.strength_overall_home))
away_strength=dict(zip(teams_df.id, teams_df.strength_overall_away))fixtures_df['team_a_strength']=fixtures_df['team_a'].map(away_strength)
fixtures_df['team_h_strength']=fixtures_df['team_h'].map(home_strength)
```

The last thing in this stop we want to do is have a column in the players dataframe for how difficult their upcoming game is. We are going to do this by [merging](https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.merge.html) the players and fixtures dataframe twice, once on the away teams and once on the home teams, calculating the dataframe and then appending them back together.

As both players and fixtures have a field called “id”, we will [drop](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.drop.html) the id from fixtures first.

```
fixtures_df=fixtures_df.drop(columns=['id'])a_players = pd.merge(players_df, fixtures_df, how="inner", left_on=["team"], right_on=["team_a"])
    h_players = pd.merge(players_df, fixtures_df, how="inner", left_on=["team"], right_on=["team_h"])a_players['diff'] = a_players['team_a_strength'] - a_players['team_h_strength']
    h_players['diff'] = h_players['team_h_strength'] - h_players['team_a_strength']players_df = a_players.append(h_players)
```

Now we can just return the players and fixtures dataframe (we won’t need the teams dataframe) and the game week.

Here is the full code for Parts 1&2:

## Part 3 — Selecting Player Out

There are 4 decisions to make each gameweek in FPL.

* Which player to transfer out.
* Which player to transfer in.
* Which players to start/sub.
* Which players to captain/vice captain

We will create 3 weightings to make each decision. These weightings are completely arbitrary and the data I use to make them in this tutorial could be completely different to what you decide to use.

As the API requires us to authenticate we will make a [requests session](https://docs.python-requests.org/en/master/user/advanced/) and log in using our username and password.

```
session = requests.session()
data = {'login' : email, 'password' : password, 'app' : 'plfpl-web', 'redirect_uri' : 'https://fantasy.premierleague.com/'}
login_url = "https://users.premierleague.com/accounts/login/"

    session.post(url=login_url, data=data)
```

We can now get our team using our teams id that we got in step 0.

```
url = "https://fantasy.premierleague.com/api/my-team/" + str(id)
team = session.get(url)
team = json.loads(team.content)
```

You will notice that this does not return all the data we need but it does return the players id. If we put it into a list we can use Pandas [loc](https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.loc.html) function to filter our players_df to return all of our players as well as all players that are not in our team using the ‘\~’ operator.

```
players = [x['element'] for x in team['picks']]
my_team = players_df.loc[players_df.id.isin(players)]
potential_players = players_df.loc[~players_df.id.isin(players)]
```

The return also includes our “bank” value which will be useful in filtering out potential players.

```
bank = team['transfers']['bank']
```

Now we get to decide how to weigh our team to transfer out players. Some factors you could use are:

* The fixture difficulty we calculated earlier.
* The players form.
* The players availability.
* The players “Expected Points” calculated by FPL.
* The players “Influence, Creativity, Threat Index” calculated by FPL.
* The players transfers in/out for the gameweek.
* Position.
* A team playing twice in a gameweek.
* The gameweek number e.g. form might not be useful in the first 10 or so gameweeks.

If you wanted to you could collect other data like betting data, weather data for the location of the game (bad weather typically means fewer goals) or FIFA player ratings.

I will use the players fixture difficulty, form, availability and I’ll give goalkeepers extra points as I don’t want to swap goalkeepers during the season. I will also use a subtractive method, giving all players 100 points and taking points away for positive metrics and adding more points for negatives.

I will also avoid using iterrows as it is too slow and we will get charged if Lambda runtime goes above 1 million ms a month (impossible if this is the only thing you are doing on Lambda but its always good to optimise).

```
def calc_out_weight(players):
    players['weight'] = 100
    players['weight']-= players['diff']/3
    players['weight']-= players['form'].astype("float")*10
    players['weight']+= (100 - players['chance_of_playing_this_round'].astype("float"))*0.2
    players.loc[players['element_type'] ==1, 'weight'] -=10
    players.loc[players['weight'] <0, 'weight'] =0return players.sample(1, weights=players.weight)
```

I returned a player based on [weighted randomness ](https://conor-aspell.medium.com/how-to-use-python-and-pandas-to-pick-a-fantasy-sports-team-4fe9afe18b2d)but you could just return the worst player to transfer out.

[https://gist.github.com/ConorAspell/2186477931c9166d8a5f26d5ebcd0e55#file-out_weights-csv](https://gist.github.com/ConorAspell/2186477931c9166d8a5f26d5ebcd0e55#file-out_weights-csv)

This is what my dataframe looks like, Son, Schmeical and Lloris all have a 0% chance of being transferred out with Zaha being the most likely to be transferred out, however, as it is [weighted randomness](https://conor-aspell.medium.com/how-to-use-python-and-pandas-to-pick-a-fantasy-sports-team-4fe9afe18b2d), Alexander-Arnold is recommended to be transferred out (Liverpool have a tough game against Chelsea this week).

## Part 4 — Deciding Player In

We want to now drop the player from our team and filter out potential players that cost too much, play in different positions or play for invalid teams (we already have 3 players from that team).

```
position = player_out.element_type.iat[0]
out_cost = player_out.now_cost.iat[0]
budget = bank + out_cost
dups_team = my_team.pivot_table(index=['team'], aggfunc='size')
invalid_teams = dups_team.loc[dups_team==3].index.tolist()potential_players=potential_players.loc[~potential_players.team.isin(invalid_teams)]
    potential_players=potential_players.loc[potential_players.element_type==position]
potential_players = potential_players.loc[potential_players.now_cost<=budget]
```

We now want to weight the potential players, its similar to what we did before in that you can use whatever data you want to weigh the players but I will use the same data as before but with an additive method this time.

```
def calc_in_weights(players):
    players['weight'] = 1
    players['weight'] += players['diff']/3
    players['weight'] += players['form'].astype("float")*10
    players['weight'] -= (100 - players['chance_of_playing_this_round'].astype("float"))*0.2
    players.loc[players['weight'] <0, 'weight'] =0return players.sample(1, weights=players.weight)
```

Again I’m choosing a random player based on their weight, it might be better just to pick the top player.

[https://gist.github.com/ConorAspell/6380d89d2f26c575b4325e85d39274a6#file-in_weights-csv](https://gist.github.com/ConorAspell/6380d89d2f26c575b4325e85d39274a6#file-in_weights-csv)

These are the top defenders recommended to be transferred in, Mings is the player selected by weighted randomness (Aston Villa are at home to Brentford).

The final weighting will be to decide the starting players and the captain/vice captain. We first add the new player into our starting team and then call the function.

```
player_in = calc_in_weights(potential_players)
my_team = my_team.append(player_in)
my_team = calc_starting_weight(my_team)
```

## Part 5 — Deciding Our Starters

We could just use the same method to get the incoming player to weight our team but I would rather put more emphasis on an easy game than form for our starters, we also need to return a data frame sorted by weight.

```
def calc_starting_weight(players):
    players['weight'] = 1
    players['weight'] += players['diff']/2
    players['weight'] += players['form'].astype("float")*5
    players['weight'] -= (100 - players['chance_of_playing_this_round'].astype("float"))*0.2
    players.loc[players['weight'] <0, 'weight'] =0
    return players.sort_values('weight', ascending=False)
```

Selecting our final team is a little complicated as we need to have just 1 goalkeeper and at least 3 defenders (2–6–2, 2–5–3 are invalid formations). I decided to just have always have just 3 defenders and run only 3–4–3 and 3–5–2 formations.

```
goalies = my_team.loc[my_team.element_type==1]defenders = my_team.loc[my_team.element_type==2]
    outfied_players = my_team.loc[my_team.element_type>2]captain = outfied_players.id.iat[0]
    vice_captain = outfied_players.id.iat[1]starters = goalies.head(1).append(defenders.head(3)).append(outfied_players.head(7))subs = goalies.tail(1).append(defenders.tail(2)).append(outfied_players.tail(1))
```

For captain, I decided to make the best midfielder or striker the captain, in this case it is Son (Tottenham are at home to Watford).

[https://gist.github.com/ConorAspell/6583ab0c6c2fb592d0c980d0fa48bbbd#file-starters-csv](https://gist.github.com/ConorAspell/6583ab0c6c2fb592d0c980d0fa48bbbd#file-starters-csv)

## Part 6 — Uploading the Changes

To upload our changes we need to make a “payload” and send it to a url. The payload should look like this:

```
{'transfers': [{'element_in': 176, 'element_out': 125, 'purchase_price': 50, 'selling_price': 50}], 'chip': None, 'entry': '6993864', 'event': 3}
```

* Element in is our player in’s id.
* Element out is our player out’s id
* Purchase price is our player in’s price
* Selling Price is our player out’s price.
* Entry is our teams’ id.
* Event is the game week.

We will also need some headers for the request:

```
headers = {'content-type': 'application/json', 'origin': 'https://fantasy.premierleague.com', 'referer': 'https://fantasy.premierleague.com/transfers'}transfers = [{"element_in" : int(player_in.id.iat[0]), "element_out" : int(player_out.id.iat[0]),"purchase_price": int(player_in.now_cost.iat[0]), "selling_price" : int(player_out.now_cost.iat[0])}]transfer_payload = { "transfers" : transfers,"chip" : None,"entry" : id,"event" : int(gameweek)}url = 'https://fantasy.premierleague.com/api/transfers/'session.post(url=url, data=json.dumps(transfer_payload), headers=headers)
```

To post our starting team, the payload should look like this:

```
'picks': [{'element': 353, 'is_captain': False, 'is_vice_captain': False, 'position': 1}, {'element': 288, 'is_captain': False, 'is_vice_captain': False, 'position': 2}...{'element': 63, 'is_captain': False, 'is_vice_captain': False, 'position': 15}], 'chip': None}
```

Some positions are reserved for certain positions i.e. goalkeepers at 1 and 12 and defenders at 2, 3 and 4. We also need to know the id of our captain and vice captain, I just set it to the 2 best midfielders/forwards.

```
captain = outfied_players.id.iat[0]
vice_captain = outfied_players.id.iat[1]
```

I decided to do a nested loop to build the payload where the outer loop gets the starters by position, builds their entry and then a second loop to get the subs and append them.

```
    picks =[]
    count = 1
    for i in range(1,5):
        players = starters.loc[starters.element_type==i]
        ids = players.id.tolist()
        for ide in ids:
            if ide == captain:
                player = {"element" : ide, "is_captain" : True, "is_vice_captain" : False, "position" : count}
            elif ide == vice_captain:
                player = {"element" : ide, "is_captain" : False, "is_vice_captain" : True, "position" : count}
            else:
                player = {"element" : ide, "is_captain" : False, "is_vice_captain" : False, "position" : count}
            picks.append(player.copy())
            count+=1
    ids = subs.id.tolist()
    for ide in ids:
        player = {"element" : ide, "is_captain" : False, "is_vice_captain" : False, "position" : count}
        picks.append(player.copy())
        count+=1
    team_sheet = {"picks" : picks,"chip" : None}
    headers = {'content-type': 'application/json', 'origin': 'https://fantasy.premierleague.com', 'referer': 'https://fantasy.premierleague.com/my-team'}
    url = 'https://fantasy.premierleague.com/api/my-team/'+str(id) + '/'
    session.post(url=url, json=team_sheet,headers=headers)
```

Here is the full code for our lambda.

[https://gist.github.com/ConorAspell/a5e694c3852c3b56db4abcb02f364241#file-part_1-py](https://gist.github.com/ConorAspell/a5e694c3852c3b56db4abcb02f364241#file-part_1-py)

## Part 7 — Making a Lambda layer

AWS Lambda is a function as a service offering, by design its meant to be the fastest, lightest, cheapest way to get code running on the cloud. However, this means that there is a limited number of python packages installed, this does not include requests or pandas.

If you have a Linux machine its possible to build a layer locally and push it to AWS but for Windows the easiest way is to go to [Cloud9](https://eu-west-1.console.aws.amazon.com/cloud9/) hit “Create Environment” > Give your environment a name and hit “Next Step” > Leave all the defaults and hit “Create Environment”.

It takes a while to start up but once it does go to the terminal in the bottom half of the screen and run the following bash commands.

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0\*0rtz6GlhH-W8FCgv.png)

```
mkdir folder
cd folder
virtualenv v-env
source ./v-env/bin/activate
pip install pandas
pip install requests
deactivate
```

Then run these commands to create the layer

```
mkdir python
cd python
cp -r ../v-env/lib64/python3.7/site-packages/* .
cd ..
zip -r panda_layer.zip python
aws lambda publish-layer-version --layer-name pandas --zip-file fileb://panda_layer.zip --compatible-runtimes python3.7
```

Finally, you should go back to [Cloud9](https://eu-west-1.console.aws.amazon.com/cloud9/) and delete the environment.

## Part 8 — Deploying the Lambda

Navigate to the [Lambda](https://eu-west-1.console.aws.amazon.com/lambda/) page and hit “Create Function”. Give your function a name and select the runtime as python 3.7.

At the bottom of the page you will see “Layers”, click “Add a layer”, navigate to “Custom Layers”, select “Pandas” and version “1”.

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1372/1\*kxN6m4WmwgZoyAnBE08HLw.png)

Next, go to configuration > general configuration and edit the timeout to 15 minutes (the maximum).

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*32qqdy7fDq805RiFu9HmkQ.png)

You can paste your code into the console or else you can put it in a zip file and upload it or you could even deploy it using the [AWS CLI](https://medium.com/swlh/create-and-deploy-an-aws-lambda-function-for-data-collection-with-the-aws-cli-ad718ec61f8a). Hit “Deploy”.

When the changes have deployed, hit “Test”, and name your test event. Hit “Test” again. If the deadline is not within the next 24 hours you should get a message like this:

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*axHe2VXJxuxts9HshIH_nA.png)

If the deadline is within 24 hours, you should get a success message instead.

The very last thing to do is to set it to trigger every 24 hours.

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*SBfHFJ7Q9IhXecEFkRe4HA.png)

Select “Add Trigger” > “Event Bridge”. Then fill in the form as in the image below.

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1330/1\*M9ZXkc8E905-PQNqmYZkdg.png)

And then hit “Add”.

The Lambda will now run once a day and only make changes in the 24 hours leading up to a deadline.

## Conclusion

This was a fun project and I recommend trying it if you are a beginner/intermediate developer interested in learning more about Pandas in Python.

If you found this useful feel free follow me on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/conor-aspell/).

title: Web3's Not So Secret Weapon
body:
The open secret to Web3’s growth is its power to manifest self fulfilling prophecies. How? By enlisting **Mission Driven Users (MDUs)**. Let me elaborate with a thought experiment.

### The A Side

Imagine you, my esteemed reader, have a start-up idea. You want to disrupt Fiverr.  You want to do that by setting up another talent marketplace that charges less than half their take-rate on transactions (10% vs Fiverr’s \~25%). How? Your plan is to only use incentivized referral programs to attract both the talent and the clients to your marketplace. Your bet is that you can then minimize spend on other sales and marketing and *voila*: your blended CAC is slashed. 

Well, you’d be unlikely to progress much further than a ppt deck. Incentivized referral programs are now [standard practice](https://www.reforge.com/brief/5-ways-to-create-viral-products#iBIwEkeVfOFmteqzNhcxCw) where they make sense. You won’t crack a sustainable advantage with them, even IF you manage to solve the cold start problem. 

You would have a tough time convincing investors. Or even entice your discerning users with a lower take rate promise. 

The A side is a no-go from the start.

### The B Side

In walks [web3](https://twitter.com/cdixon/status/1444072365822857219?s=20).

[https://twitter.com/cdixon/status/1442201625590779909](https://twitter.com/cdixon/status/1442201625590779909)

You can now use code to reward ‘equity’ in exchange for valuable user actions. At scale! So you take your deck and update it. Instead of selling equity to VCs and using the proceeds to fund a referral program; you bypass the middleman and offer the equity directly to your user base. Seems like a subtle change at first. You wonder if it would even fundamentally change your unit economics assumptions.

Yet, the B-side uplift could be profound.

### What’s the uplift hypothesis?

To start with, you now have a powerful narrative to rally users: *a low-cost marketplace owned and governed by those who help create it*.

Much more moving than *“I will offer you 10% instead of 25%”.*

When your users buy into your vision, they pay more attention to what they can do to help you. Not solely out of the generosity of their spirits. They know that helping you earns them your equity. They can unlock asymmetric returns that until now have been inaccessible to all but a selected few founders and VCs. **The narrative, the agency and the motive are the three powerful ingredients that give you your secret weapon: Mission Driven Users (MDUs).**

MDUs have a lot of similarities to early employees of a mission driven company. They go above and beyond base expectations:

* MDUs dig much deeper into their contact books and spend much more social capital to promote your marketplace compared to normal users. [Braintrust](https://www.usebraintrust.com/) - the first user-owned talent marketplace (and one of the most intriguing non finance web3 projects) - has created a global community of [700k freelancers](https://www.usebraintrust.com/blog/growth-report-24) (pending confirmation) and $35m in gross service volume run rate one year after launch with “[zero marketing dollars spent outside their referral engine](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J6upkcecUpE)”
* MDUs are stickier and more forgiving. Look at the passion with which the Ethereum developer ecosystem perseveres despite persistent challenges around [scalability, cost and volatil](https://www.notboring.co/p/own-the-internet)ity. Keeping with the Braintrust example, the “website feedback” channel on its [Discord Serve](https://discord.gg/rgUS9aHFCB)r is filled with constructive feedback from its 45k members
* MDUs may even contribute to the operations. In Braintrust, community members participate in day to day operations by [vetting talent, creating L&D content, or even contributing code to the development of the platform](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J6upkcecUpE)

In short, MDUs reduce your CAC, increase your LTV and improve your operating leverage. You just might be able to slash your take rate after all. Your marketplace is starting to look disruptive.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/whuy8lbBb4OAyeuKKXnOO.png?height=1423&width=2880)

### Of course there is always a ‘but’

Before rushing out to start your user owned marketplace - there are a few points to worth considering:

1. *Equity incentives might not resonate in all corners of the market.* A more risk-averse user persona (e.g. freelance lawyer or management consultants) or more cash strapped ones (eg [ride hailing drivers](https://techcrunch.com/2018/03/02/mit-study-shows-how-much-driving-for-uber-or-lyft-sucks/) pre pandemic) may put more value on cash today than the equity you offer them. If cash is worth more to your users, it would be harder to align incentives for the long term and beyond an initial transaction. And financial user incentives in general may not be appropriate at all in some corners: enterprise users or public sector employees
2. *The MDU effect may wear off at scale.* When your tokens are accessible by everyone and you’ve scaled to a certain point; your MDU effect is likely to wear off. Your users won’t have privileged access to the upside. And the upside is more limited now. And they will have less incremental impact in helping you grow further. At some point owning a Braintrust token will not be dissimilar to owning a Fiverr stock with more influence. So you would have to make sure you have other growth engines in place by then to sustain your advantage
3. *Tokens are not free.* Tokens can be many things: utility tokens (similar to loyalty points, usable within the ecosystem) or governance tokens (similar to equities and tradable for cash usually). But they are not free. The former has an opportunity cost of lost revenue in one way or another. The latter is the equity you have sold to your user instead of an investor. The challenge you will face in both scenarios is that it is very difficult for an early stage project to put a dollar amount on these and make informed decisions on your spend
4. *Your valuation becomes a compounding loop.* As your valuation grows, your MDUs are more incentivized to help you grow, and their actions help grow your marketplace which in turn leads to your valuation increasing. A virtuous cycle that’s missing in traditional companies. But the reverse will also be true. Crypto market trends push your valuations down. Your MDUs may become less inclined to earn your tokens. Your growth engine slows. Your marketplace is now worth less. Your MDUs are even less excited to help you grow the marketplace
5. *Token issuance could become more strictly regulated in the US.* There is some uncertainty about what type of token would the [SEC consider an equity](https://www-cdn.law.stanford.edu/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Mendelson_20180129.pdf). The stricter the SEC’s interpretation of the Howey Test vis-a-vis tokens is, the more cost prohibitive it would be for you to use tokens as an answer to your cold start problem

### Should you be taking this experiment?

All the said, will your marketplace be as disruptive as your pitchdeck claims? The answer is a very confident: maybe! Nuance is definitely less exciting, but hopefully more compelling.

But here’s a checklist that might help you assess if your marketplace lands on the ‘yes’ side of the spectrum:

* Is equity (ie promise of asymmetric returns at a future date) a meaningful incentive for your users?
* Do you have a compelling narrative to capture their imagination?
* Do you have a clear set of actions they can perform to help (and earn your tokens)?
* Do you have some initial ideas on how to sustain an edge once you scale and your MDUs naturally transition into being just ‘U’s

Tick these boxes and dive in. Web3’s potential is mind bending and it’s by no means limited to user owned marketplaces.

Or if you want to learn more, here is a non-exhaustive list of resources I found very helpful:

* Educational material: [Andreessen Horrowitz Crypto Start-up School](https://a16z.com/crypto-startup-school/)
* Books: [Token Economy](https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/54222022-token-economy), [Blockchain Basics](https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/34137265-blockchain-basics), or [The Infinite Machine](https://www.goodreads.com/en/book/show/50175330-the-infinite-machine)
* Join [SeedClub’s Discord](https://discord.gg/42UjJskuEF)
* Packy McCormick’s Essays on [Ethereum](https://www.notboring.co/p/own-the-internet), [Solana](https://www.notboring.co/p/solana-summer), and [DAOs](https://www.notboring.co/p/the-cooperation-economy-)
* Listen to [The Defiant](https://thedefiant.io/podcast/) or [The Bankless](http://podcast.banklesshq.com/) podcasts

### About Me

I’ve spent the past seven years building and scaling marketplaces in product or leadership roles. Before that I was a strategy consultant. At the time of writing this article, I’m a web3 newbie; \~2 months into the journey. If you see any flaws in my logic, please reach out to me and help me learn more. You can find me on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/AmiraliMohajer). Or on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/amiralimohajer/).

### Credits

* Cover photo by [Alina Grubnyak](https://unsplash.com/@alinnnaaaa)
* Growth frameworks alluded to are by [Reforge](https://www.reforge.com/). I highly recommend their courses/content

* Is equity (ie promise of asymmetric returns at a future date) a meaningful incentive for your users?
* Do you have a compelling narrative to capture their imagination?
* Do you have a clear set of actions they can perform to help (and earn your tokens)?
* Do you have some initial ideas on how to sustain an edge once you scale and your MDUs naturally transition into being just ‘U’s

title: Web3's Not So Secret Weapon
body:
The open secret to Web3’s growth is its power to manifest self fulfilling prophecies. How? By enlisting **Mission Driven Users (MDUs)**. Let me elaborate with a thought experiment.

### The A Side

Imagine you, my esteemed reader, have a start-up idea. You want to disrupt Fiverr.  You want to do that by setting up another talent marketplace that charges less than half their take-rate on transactions (10% vs Fiverr’s \~25%). How? Your plan is to only use incentivized referral programs to attract both the talent and the clients to your marketplace. Your bet is that you can then minimize spend on other sales and marketing and *voila*: your blended CAC is slashed.

Well, you’d be unlikely to progress much further than a ppt deck. Incentivized referral programs are now [standard practice](https://www.reforge.com/brief/5-ways-to-create-viral-products#iBIwEkeVfOFmteqzNhcxCw) where they make sense. You won’t crack a sustainable advantage with them, even IF you manage to solve the cold start problem.

You would have a tough time convincing investors. Or even entice your discerning users with a lower take rate promise.

The A side is a no-go from the start.

### The B Side

In walks [web3](https://twitter.com/cdixon/status/1444072365822857219?s=20).

[https://twitter.com/cdixon/status/1442201625590779909](https://twitter.com/cdixon/status/1442201625590779909)

You can now use code to reward ‘equity’ in exchange for valuable user actions. At scale!

So you take your deck and update it. Instead of selling equity to investors and using the proceeds to fund your referral program; you bypass the middleman and offer the equity directly to your user base. For every successful referral, they now receive a small fraction of the equity in the marketplace. Seems like a subtle change at first. You wonder if it would even fundamentally change your unit economics assumptions.

Yet, the B-side uplift could be profound.

### What’s the uplift hypothesis?

To start with, you now have a powerful narrative to rally users: *a low-cost marketplace owned and governed by those who help create it*.

Much more moving than *“I will offer you 10% instead of 25%”.*

When your users buy into your vision, they pay more attention to what they can do to help you. Not solely out of the generosity of their spirits. They know that helping you earns them your equity. And **access** to your early stage equity is worth more to them than cash. They can unlock asymmetric returns that until now have been inaccessible to all but a selected few founders and VCs.

**The narrative, the agency and the motive are the three powerful ingredients that give you your secret weapon: Mission Driven Users (MDUs).** MDUs have a lot of similarities to early employees of a mission driven company. They go above and beyond base expectations:

* MDUs dig much deeper into their contact books and spend much more social capital to promote your marketplace compared to normal users. [Braintrust](https://www.usebraintrust.com/) - the first user-owned talent marketplace (and one of the most intriguing non finance web3 projects) - has created a global community of [700k freelancers](https://www.usebraintrust.com/blog/growth-report-24) (pending confirmation) and $35m in gross service volume run rate one year after launch with “[zero marketing dollars spent outside their referral engine](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J6upkcecUpE)”. And they already have enterprises like Goldman Sachs, Nestle, and Nike working with them (though credit for these also goes to the experienced [founding team](https://www.usebraintrust.com/about))
* MDUs are stickier and more forgiving. Look at the passion with which the Ethereum developer ecosystem perseveres despite persistent challenges around [scalability, cost and volatil](https://www.notboring.co/p/own-the-internet)ity. Keeping with the Braintrust example, the “website feedback” channel on its [Discord Serve](https://discord.gg/rgUS9aHFCB)r is filled with constructive feedback from its 45k members. Think about the probability of you giving detailed and continuous feedback to a young start-up you’ve tested as a user, when there are plenty of existing alternatives!
* MDUs may even contribute to the operations. In Braintrust, community members participate in day to day operations by [vetting talent, creating L&D content, or even contributing code to the development of the platform](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J6upkcecUpE). Bounty programs, where token prizes are offered for completion of a specific project by the community, are standard practice in web3. Key advantages of bounty programs compared to typical crowdfunding projects are (a) deep familiarity of participants with the project and its context; and (b) alignment of the participants interest with the outcome of the project beyond a one-off transaction

In short, MDUs reduce your CAC, increase your LTV and improve your operating leverage. You just might be able to slash your take rate after all. Your marketplace is starting to look disruptive.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/whuy8lbBb4OAyeuKKXnOO.png?height=1423&width=2880)

### Of course there is always a ‘but’

Before rushing out to start your user owned marketplace - there are a few points to worth considering:

1. *Equity incentives might not resonate in all corners of the market.* A more risk-averse user persona (e.g. freelance lawyer or management consultants) or more cash strapped ones (eg [ride hailing drivers](https://techcrunch.com/2018/03/02/mit-study-shows-how-much-driving-for-uber-or-lyft-sucks/) pre pandemic) may put more value on cash today than the equity you offer them. If cash is worth more to your users, it would be harder to align incentives for the long term and beyond an initial transaction. And financial user incentives in general may not be appropriate at all in some corners: enterprise users or public sector employees
2. *The MDU effect may wear off at scale.* When your tokens are accessible by everyone and you’ve scaled to a certain point; your MDU effect is likely to wear off. Your users won’t have privileged access to the upside. And the upside is more limited now. And they will have less incremental impact in helping you grow further. At some point owning a Braintrust token will not be dissimilar to owning a Fiverr stock with more influence. So you would have to make sure you have other growth engines in place by then to sustain your advantage
3. *Tokens are not free.* Tokens can be many things: utility tokens (similar to loyalty points, usable within the ecosystem) or governance tokens (similar to equities and tradable for cash usually). But they are not free. The former has an opportunity cost of lost revenue in one way or another. The latter is the equity you have sold to your user instead of an investor. The challenge you will face in both scenarios is that it is very difficult for an early stage project to put a dollar amount on these and make informed decisions on your spend
4. *Your valuation becomes a compounding loop.* As your valuation grows, your MDUs are more incentivized to help you grow, and their actions help grow your marketplace which in turn leads to your valuation increasing. A virtuous cycle that’s missing in traditional companies. But the reverse will also be true. Crypto market trends push your valuations down. Your MDUs may become less inclined to earn your tokens. Your growth engine slows. Your marketplace is now worth less. Your MDUs are even less excited to help you grow the marketplace
5. *Token issuance could become more strictly regulated in the US.* There is some uncertainty about what type of token would the [SEC consider an equity](https://www-cdn.law.stanford.edu/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Mendelson_20180129.pdf). The stricter the SEC’s interpretation of the Howey Test vis-a-vis tokens is, the more cost prohibitive it would be for you to use tokens as an answer to your cold start problem

### Should you be taking this experiment?

All the said, will your marketplace be as disruptive as your pitchdeck claims? The answer is a very confident: maybe! Nuance is definitely less exciting, but hopefully more compelling.

But here’s a checklist that might help you assess if your marketplace lands on the ‘yes’ side of the spectrum:

* Is equity (ie promise of asymmetric returns at a future date) a meaningful incentive for your users?
* Do you have a compelling narrative to capture their imagination?
* Do you have a clear set of actions they can perform to help (and earn your tokens)?
* Do you have some initial ideas on how to sustain an edge once you scale and your MDUs naturally transition into being just ‘U’s

Tick these boxes and dive in. Web3’s potential is mind bending and it’s by no means limited to user owned marketplaces.

Or if you want to learn more, here is a non-exhaustive list of resources I found very helpful:

* Educational material: [Andreessen Horrowitz Crypto Start-up School](https://a16z.com/crypto-startup-school/)
* Books: [Token Economy](https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/54222022-token-economy), [Blockchain Basics](https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/34137265-blockchain-basics), or [The Infinite Machine](https://www.goodreads.com/en/book/show/50175330-the-infinite-machine)
* Join [SeedClub’s Discord](https://discord.gg/42UjJskuEF)
* Packy McCormick’s Essays on [Ethereum](https://www.notboring.co/p/own-the-internet), [Solana](https://www.notboring.co/p/solana-summer), and [DAOs](https://www.notboring.co/p/the-cooperation-economy-)
* Listen to [The Defiant](https://thedefiant.io/podcast/) or [The Bankless](http://podcast.banklesshq.com/) podcasts

### About Me

I’ve spent the past seven years building and scaling marketplaces in product or leadership roles. Before that I was a strategy consultant. At the time of writing this article, I’m a web3 newbie; \~2 months into the journey. If you see any flaws in my logic, please reach out to me and help me learn more. You can find me on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/AmiraliMohajer). Or on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/amiralimohajer/).

title: Bitcoin and Cryptocurrency #1  - Sheng Kai Kim
body:
## The Consensus rule that completely disregard the power in organizations

I sunk deep in thoughts after listening to one of the podcasts from Jordan Peterson, named "Bitcoin: The Future of Money", exploring the depths of bitcoin compared to the fiat currency that we have long been used.

It seems to me that Bitcoin is the catalyst to get into the new dimension. As romantic of an idea it may seem, it is undeniable that it broke the structure of power within organizations.

In management practice and theory, power is the one central concept, perhaps most notable in politics where the elites have the highest authority. One of the most obvious examples related to economics is the scarcity of currency. The authority can determine that a piece of paper holds intrinsic value to trade and exchange.

However, to the surprise of many, Bitcoin is not defined by anyone or any power. It is an open-source computer code that is accessible to anyone, but there exists a chain of rules hard-coded in itself, called the consensus rule. In simpler terms, if you were to invest in Bitcoin, you have to follow the rule of the game itself that is agreed upon by the community, and it throws off the central concept of power in this organization.

   曾经有人评价道《CLANNAD》讲述的不是少女漫画，而是人生！ KEY社的经典之作CLANNAD,KANON,AIR和一般的动画片有所不同,它们注重的不是特别精彩或是激烈的场面,而是通过生活之间的点点滴滴的小事例(不论是悲伤的，还是高兴的)来渲染出亲情,爱情及友情带给人们的幸福或悲伤的感受,而这些情感往往是在这一个纷繁复杂的社会中被忽略或是扭曲的的情感,并且CLANNAD所描述的家庭,亲情这一主题更是在现实生活中被淡化了的情感.因此,CLANNAD作为一部描述家族亲情的作品,从内心深处给予了人们感动,让人们重新意识到亲情的伟大和重要性. 
 感觉故事很无聊可能是因为这部动画片是由游戏改编来的,之前的剧情铺垫很多才导致没兴趣看.可是个人觉得这部动画片之所以人气这么高必然有值得人们去追捧它的理由,而且之后的剧情都十分感人,第二季中的故事更是将整部作品的剧情推向了巅峰,配上绝妙的音乐(KEY社的音乐似乎很多都是神作呢),使作品主题得以体现和升华. 
 最后插一句，如果认真对待这部作品的人，看完后不哭那就是冷血了……
